Escavalier can attempt to stomach one attack from Tyrantrum and fire back with Iron Head, although Escavalier's unboosted Iron Head won't be able to OHKO Tyrantrum without prior damage.

Fighting-types: Offensive Fighting-types such as Virizion and Toxicroak outrun Choice Band Tyrantrum and threaten with super effective Fighting-type STAB attacks. Other Fighting-types like Bewear and Sawk beat every variant of Tyrantrum 1v1, and Choice Scarf Passimian can handle most variants.

Faster Attackers: Tyrantrum dislikes taking hits, as it takes substantial damage from nearly any sort of invested attack, and being able to take it down before it can move is a great way to limit its damage output. Choice Band Tyrantrum is easy to deal with in this regard, as it is rather slow and thus falls prey to various faster Pokemon, such as Shaymin, Mega Glalie, Goodra, and Sneasel, but be aware that most offensive Pokemon that fail to OHKO Tyrantrum risk getting OHKOed in return. Choice Scarf Tyrantrum is harder to outrun, but faster Choice Scarf users such as Gardevoir, Flygon, Shaymin, and Speed Boost Pokemon such as Yanmega, and weather sweepers such as Venusaur can revenge kill Tyrantrum and prevent it from cleaning. Tyrantrum's high Defense stat means it can take most priority moves, but Ice Shard from Mega Glalie and Sucker Punch from Honchkrow can still do decent damage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Head Smash is Tyrantrum's primary STAB move, crushing a large majority of offensive Pokemon and potentially 2HKOing even those that resist it, such as Flygon and Virizion. Outrage hits offensive Pokemon that resist Rock, notably OHKOing Flygon while doing substantial damage to Virizion. It also can be a good late-game cleaning tool, as it boasts perfect accuracy over Head Smash. Earthquake hits Steel-types such as Registeel. Dragon Claw is a reliable STAB move that can pick off weakened foes or opposing Dragon-types, such as Flygon, Zygarde-10%, and Goodra, with much less risk than its other STAB attacks. However, it's only barely stronger than a resisted Head Smash, so it's usually not worth going for in most cases. Toxic can be an option, and while it is not a move you'd choose in a majority of circumstances, it may be the only way Tyrantrum can have some presence against bulky Pokemon that can heal off its blows such as Cresselia and Slowbro.

Set Details

A Jolly nature is necessary for Choice Scarf Tyrantrum to outspeed the likes of Jolteon, Swellow, and Salazzle, and full Attack investment simply maximizes the power of Head Smash for it to effortlessly KO most offensive Pokemon that don't resist it.

Usage Tips

Choice Scarf Tyrantrum's main role is to threaten offensive teams with Head Smash, which has enough power to 2HKO Flygon and Virizion after Stealth Rock damage, meaning that offensive teams have limited switch-ins to Tyrantrum and are quite prone to losing Pokemon to it. Keep an eye out for offensive Pokemon like Rhyperior that can switch into Head Smash and try to hit them with the appropriate coverage move or pull a double switch to maintain offensive momentum. However, be wary of any Fairy-types present if attempting to use Outrage, as it can mean Tyrantrum's premature end. Be sure to capitalize on Choice Scarf Tyrantrum's power over Aerodactyl, which checks most of the Pokemon Tyrantrum does while being able to switch moves and have access to Pursuit.

Team Options

Since this Tyrantrum set is designed to prey on offensive teams, partners that can take on bulkier teams are appreciated. Escavalier is a very solid teammate, as it can switch into and threaten Fairy-, Ice-, and Dragon-type Pokemon for Tyrantrum and help put additional pressure on bulky Pokemon that intend to take hits from Tyrantrum, skewering the likes of Cresselia and Slowbro. Escavalier can also Pursuit trap Bronzong, removing another obstacle for Tyrantrum. In turn, Tyrantrum can protect Escavalier from Fire-type attacks and threaten a vast majority of fast Pokemon. Other wallbreakers and holepunchers include Flame Orb Machamp, Pangoro, Shaymin, and Toxicroak, which can harass slower teams, but be mindful of their shared weaknesses with Tyrantrum.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Head Smash is Tyrantrum's main STAB attack and is strong enough to 2HKO Bronzong, meaning only the bulkiest of Pokemon that resist Rock can hope to stomach it. Outrage dents Ground- and Fighting-types looking to resist Head Smash, heavily damages Donphan, 2HKOes Rhyperior after Stealth Rock damage, and is accurate, unlike Head Smash. Earthquake's main use is to smash Pokemon like Registeel and Steelix that can take Tyrantrum's STAB moves.

Tyrantrum's last moveslot is largely filler, and it is mostly used to help Tyrantrum continue wallbreaking targets while still making it difficult for checks to switch in. Superpower helps to take out bulky Pokemon such as Umbreon and Snorlax while still deterring Steel-types such as Bronzong and Registeel from switching in. Crunch can be used to 2HKO specially defensive Cresselia without the risky effects of Head Smash and Outrage as well as cripple Bronzong. Dragon Claw is an option by virtue of simply being a safe STAB move to throw out, notably being able to damage Head Smash switch-ins without locking into Outrage, but its wallbreaking power is low otherwise.

Set Details

An Adamant nature with a Choice Band maximizes Tyrantrum's damage output against bulky Pokemon. A Jolly nature may be used to get the drop on the 242 speed tier, which includes relevant Pokemon like Florges, Mandibuzz, and Cresselia.

Usage Tips

Tyrantrum primarily targets slower Pokemon, against which it can use Head Smash and brutalize any Pokemon that doesn't resist the move. Head Smash's obscene power and lack of a crippling drawback aside from accuracy mean this will be Tyrantrum's most used attack. While Tyrantrum can predict the opponent's switch to a bulky Pokemon that resists Rock and use its other moves to nail them coming in, the best time for Tyrantrum to use its coverage moves is if they can KO the initial target while covering the switch at the same time. Since the opponent will rarely have more than one Pokemon that can take Head Smashes well, Tyrantrum usually only needs to get a single correct prediction to be free to spam Head Smash throughout the match. Against more offensive teams, Tyrantrum is not expected to survive for long due to its middling Speed and common weaknesses. Thus, it should focus on busting open a huge hole whenever it can, taking advantage of any slower or offensively weaker Pokemon on the opponent's team as well as the fact that they do not possess good switch-ins to Tyrantrum.

Team Options

Fast Pokemon that can clean games, such as Swellow, Dragon Dance Zygarde-10%, Salazzle, and Yanmega, make great partners to Tyrantrum, as these Pokemon greatly appreciate Tyrantrum softening up the foe's team to have an easier time sweeping. Tyrantrum can also lure out and weaken or KO problematic Pokemon for these sweepers, such as Bronzong and Rhyperior, as well as provide mild defensive synergy with Salazzle, as it resists Fairy-, Steel-, and Ice-type moves for it. Tyrantrum especially appreciates VoltTurn support to be able to switch into bulky Pokemon with minimal risk and can be provided by fast Pokemon such as Swellow, Noivern, Raikou, and Flygon. Tyrantrum also benefits from many forms of speed control, such as Sticky Web and paralysis, to gain an advantage against faster targets, making any potential users of these moves, such as Galvantula, Cresselia, Slowbro, and Porygon2 helpful teammates.

sets.name: Rock Polish
sets.description:
Moves

Outrage is Tyrantrum's secondary STAB move, and coupled with Dragonium Z, it can be used to hit most Rock-resistant Pokemon such as Rhyperior and Bewear. However, locking into Outrage can be very dangerous if the opponent has a Fairy- or Steel-type that can KO Tyrantrum, such as Gardevoir or Metagross. Earthquake lets Tyrantrum hit Steel-types such as Registeel, which resist both of its STAB moves.

Set Details

Maximum Attack and Speed investment allows Tyrantrum to maximize its offensive presence. A Jolly nature is necessary to outspeed base 100 Speed Choice Scarf users such as Shaymin and Flygon, which would otherwise revenge kill Tyrantrum after a Rock Polish. However, sacrificing those advantages for an Adamant nature is an option if you prefer the extra power behind Tyrantrum's attacks, notably allowing it to OHKO Shaymin after some prior chip damage. Dragonium Z allows Tyrantrum to bypass its would-be checks, such as Rhyperior and Bewear, while Rockium Z lets it drop a nuke on neutral targets while bypassing Head Smash's shaky accuracy. If already using a Z-Move on your team, Rock Incense is a decent option to strengthen the power of Head Smash. This does lack the explosive power of Z-Moves that lets Tyantrum get past specific checks, though. Groundium Z is a serviceable option that lets Tyrantrum nail Pokemon such as non-Shuca Berry Metagross.

Usage Tips

Rock Polish Tyrantrum is able to bluff a Choice Scarf set, being able to set up on frail, offensive Pokemon such as Aerodactyl, Ninetales, and Swellow that fear its Choice Scarf set while also having a decent matchup versus bulkier teams due to the one-time nuke that Dragonium Z provides. Due to Tyrantrum's decent defensive typing, it is able to find setup opportunities from switching into common offensive Pokemon like Salazzle and setting up as they're forced out. Tyrantrum also finds setup opportunities on Choice-locked Pokemon such as Escavalier locked into Pursuit. Be wary of clicking Outrage when a Fairy-type such as Florges or Gardevoir is present on the opponent's field since the Fairy-type would gain a free turn. Against bulkier teams, make sure to gauge when the time is right to use the Z-Move, as eliminating a Rock-resistant Pokemon early-game can be extremely beneficial for Tyrantrum and leave it far less prediction reliant. For example, if you successfully eliminate a Rhyperior early-game, Tyrantrum can more easily spam Head Smash with little consequence. Steel-types such as Bronzong should be eliminated before attempting a Tyrantrum sweep, since they aren't hit by Earthquake hard enough and can stop a +2 Tyrantrum in its tracks.

Team Options

Wallbreakers such as Mega Abomasnow, Ninetales, and Choice Band Escavalier can pave the way for a Tyrantrum sweep due to them being able to wear down common answers for it, such as Bronzong. Pursuit from the likes of Escavalier and Drapion is able to weaken Pokemon like Bronzong and Cresselia for Tyrantrum. Tyrantrum appreciates support from Spikes setters like Roserade, Mega Glalie, and Golisopod, since many of its checks, such as Shuca Berry Metagross and Nidoqueen, lack reliable recovery, making them prone to being weakened by repeated switches into spikes. Pokemon that can beat opposing Steel-types are a must, since Tyrantrum cannot sweep if they are present. Bewear and Fire Blast Nidoqueen are good examples of wallbreakers that can neuter Steel-types. Grass-types such as Shaymin and Virizion are able to depend on Tyrantrum to take Fire- and Flying-type attacks for them and set up on these attacks. In return, Grass-types can weaken prominent Ground-types like Rhyperior, which threaten Tyrantrum's ability to sweep.

Goodra.overview: Goodra's ability and typing, which give it a Grass-type immunity and Electric, Fire, and Water resistances, combined with great bulk let Goodra act as a fantastic sponge that can check offensive threats such as Roserade, Raikou, Ninetales, and Salazzle and switch into bulky Water-type Pokemon such as Milotic. On top of this, Goodra's respectable Speed gives it the ability to run Choice Scarf, outpacing Choice Scarf Tyrantrum and Aerodactyl. Goodra's solid Special Attack and amazing coverage make Choice Specs also great, as it renders Goodra hugely threatening to bulky offense and balance teams by hitting a wide range of Pokemon. However, Choice Scarf Goodra is pressured by popular Fairy- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Florges and Registeel, which are easily able to switch into most of its attacks and can use Goodra as setup fodder if it isn't careful about what it locks itself into. Furthermore, Goodra has no reliable recovery and is easily chipped away by status, entry hazards, and Pokemon that it can check.
Goodra.comments:
Other Options

Assault Vest Goodra with Dragon Tail in order to phaze checks can be used to more reliably check special attackers. However, this set is worse than both Choice Specs and Choice Scarf because it is checked easier by bulky Pokemon and its only value over other Assault Vest users in the tier is its Grass immunity. Choice Band Goodra can also be used in favor of Choice Specs to wallbreak. However, Outrage is an unreliable move that makes it easy for revenge killers to KO Goodra.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Goodra, especially the Choice Scarf set, is walled heavily by Florges and forced out. The Choice Specs set is pressured and is forced into making a prediction if a Fairy-type such as Gardevoir or Florges is on the opposing team. Goodra is reluctant to spam Draco Meteor and has to get a Sludge Wave off on Florges to do anything.

Steel-types: Registeel and Bronzong are very bulky and can take multiple Fire Blasts from Choice Scarf Goodra. Goodra is forced to predict when Steel-types are going to be switched in and is pressured by this. Unfortunately, Goodra still needs to hit multiple Fire Blasts even if getting the prediction right.

Dragon-types: Goodra is very easily revenge killed by faster Dragon-type Pokemon such as Zygarde-10% and Flygon.

Physical Attackers: Due to Goodra's poor Defense, physically strong Pokemon that outspeed Goodra such as Virizion, Zygarde-10%, Flygon, and Lycanroc-D will almost always force it out.

Special Walls: Pokemon such as Assault Vest Slowking are easy switch-ins to Goodra, especially when the Choice Scarf set is used. Other Pokemon like Mantine, Florges, and specially defensive Mandibuzz can only be hit hard if hit with the correct move or if Goodra is running Choice Specs.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Draco Meteor is Goodra's most powerful STAB move and dishes out high damage on targets hit neutrally by it. Thunderbolt is used to hit Water-type Pokemon such as Mega Blastoise and Araquanid. Fire Blast is used for coverage on Steel-type Pokemon such as Metagross and Registeel. Earthquake allows Goodra to deal with Calm Mind Raikou and more reliably revenge kill Pokemon like Salazzle, as its accuracy is superior to that of Draco Meteor. Ice Beam can be used over Draco Meteor to hit Pokemon like Zygarde-10%, Noivern, Flygon, and other Dragon-type Pokemon for super effective damage without losing stats or having a chance to miss. However, Ice Beam is a lot weaker and leaves no real option to heavily damage foes neutral to Dragon.

Set Details

Maximum Speed investment, a Timid nature, and Choice Scarf allow Goodra to Speed tie with other Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Gardevoir as well as outpace the entire unboosted metagame bar Mega Sceptile. Sap Sipper gives Goodra an immunity to Grass-type moves, allowing it to switch into Grass-types like Shaymin more easily. A Hasty nature alternatively allows Goodra to keep maximum Speed and some Attack in order to make use of Earthquake better.

Usage Tips

Goodra should primarily be used as a revenge killer, having the Speed and moveset to take on Pokemon such as Tyrantrum, Noivern, Salazzle, and Zygarde-10%. Make sure to use Fire Blast when predicting Steel-type Pokemon that wish to take advantage of Draco Meteor. If the opponent has a Florges or Registeel, try to predict what moves to use or what switches to make in order to not waste turns dealing little damage. Even though Goodra is offensive, it can still soft check Pokemon such as Roserade and Salazzle. Try to make use of Goodra's bulk and typing to check Pokemon as well as revenge killing. Be aware of status and entry hazards when using Goodra, as it has no reliable recovery. Too much damage over time leaves Goodra open to priority users such as Golisopod, Zygarde-10%, and Honchkrow. Watch out for locking into the wrong move, like Thunderbolt against a team with Dragon Dance Zygarde-10%.

Team Options

Goodra has the ability to revenge kill and force switches, so entry hazards are good because they cause chip damage to the opponent's checks. Registeel, Metagross, Roserade, and Nidoqueen work especially well, as they also cover Goodra's Fairy-type weakness. Water-types are very good alongside Goodra thanks to its Electric resistance and ability to check Grass-type Pokemon with Sap Sipper. Mega Blastoise and Golisopod work very well with Goodra offensively, whereas Milotic and Slowbro work well defensively and also cover Goodra's weakness to physical attackers. Steel-type Pokemon such as Registeel, Metagross, Bronzong, and Escavalier can switch into Gardevoir and Florges, which check Goodra. Poison-type Pokemon like Nidoqueen, Roserade, and Salazzle are also very good checks to Florges. Fairy-type Pokemon such as Florges and Gardevoir help to remove threats to Goodra like Noivern, Flygon, and Zygarde-10%. Florges and Gardevoir also have the ability to keep Goodra healthy with Wish, Heal Bell, and Healing Wish. Physical walls such as Tangela and Slowbro can work alongside Goodra well defensively, as they are able to make up for Goodra's lacking physical bulk.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Moves

Choice Specs-boosted Draco Meteor can put a huge dent into anything that doesn't resist it, being able to 2HKO specially defensive Pokemon such as Araquanid without needing to use Thunderbolt. Fire Blast nukes Steel-type Pokemon, sending Metagross packing as well as 2HKOing Bronzong. Thunderbolt deals with Araquanid more consistently and 2HKOes Milotic after Stealth Rock damage. Sludge Wave prevents Fairy-type Pokemon from switching into Goodra, as it 2HKOes Florges and OHKOes Gardevoir after Stealth Rock. Thunder allows Goodra to hit Water-types harder than Thunderbolt does. It has a chance to OHKO Mandibuzz and Mega Blastoise as well as being able to potentially paralyze faster Pokemon. Ice Beam is an option over Sludge Wave if you have teammates to exploit Florges.

Set Details

Maximum Speed investment with a Timid nature allows Goodra to outspeed Pokemon such as Mega Blastoise, Tyrantrum, and Necrozma. Sap Sipper makes sure that Goodra can still check some Grass-type Pokemon such as Roserade and Shaymin.

Usage Tips

Choice Specs Goodra is a powerful wallbreaker, hitting bulky Pokemon such as Milotic, Metagross, and Florges heavily with coverage moves as well as being able to OHKO Pokemon such as Mega Blastoise with Draco Meteor. If you wish for Goodra to break through a team easier, you will need to correctly predict in order to get rid of its checks. Sludge Wave on a predicted Florges or Fire Blast on a predicted Registeel will go a long way towards Goodra winning. Goodra still has a good Special Defense stat, so despite being offensive, it can still check a lot of special attackers like Ninetales and Roserade. Sap Sipper should be used to check Grass-types that rely on Grass-type attacks to deal heavy damage such as Shaymin and Roserade.

Team Options

Choice Specs Goodra is a wallbreaker and forces a lot of switches, so entry hazard setters are very important. Registeel, Metagross, Roserade, and Nidoqueen work especially well, as they also cover Goodra's Fairy-type weakness. Goodra can remove a lot of bulkier Pokemon, leaving the door wide open for a sweeper. Choice Scarf users such as Gardevoir, Noivern, Flygon, and Shaymin can all take advantage of Goodra's ability to remove walls from the match. Both Shaymin and Gardevoir also help support Goodra with Healing Wish. Goodra still needs support to avoid being revenge killed by heavy-hitting physical attackers. Pokemon like Slowbro and Tangela can help to pivot in on these Pokemon. Fairy- and Steel-type Pokemon work well with Goodra, as they can come in on Dragon- and Fairy-type attacks that threaten out Goodra. Florges and Registeel work well defensively, whereas Gardevoir and Metagross can work more offensively. Goodra's Sap Sipper, as well as its useful Electric resistance, can help Water-type teammates like Golisopod, Milotic, and Slowbro.

Zygarde-10%.overview: Zygarde-10% is blessed with Thousand Arrows, a move widely regarded as the best offensive move in the game, making it a premier offensive threat in RarelyUsed. Zygarde-10% has a great STAB combination that allows it to pressure the almost omnipresent Steel-types of the tier while also hitting Pokemon resistant to Ground with Outrage. Zygarde-10%'s Speed tier lets it outpace most of the tier, including the likes of Virizion, Espeon, and Mismagius. Although its immediate power is rather low when compared to other Ground-types such as Rhyperior or even Donphan, Zygarde-10% can fix this with Dragon Dance and Dragonium Z, working wonders as a fast cleaner, or with a Choice Band, offering raw power to wallbreak. However, Zygarde-10% struggles to break past defensive Pokemon like Porygon2, Slowbro, and Cresselia, which have no problem switching into its attacks and forcing it out. It is also held back by its lackluster bulk, meaning it can only switch into or set up on some resisted moves and more passive Pokemon, such as Registeel. It is also very vulnerable to priority users if not locked into Extreme Speed, especially against those with Ice Shard. Having only Outrage as a reliable Dragon-type STAB move also makes it vulnerable to being revenge killed by Steel- or Fairy-type Pokemon, so it has to choose wisely when to use the attack.
Zygarde-10%.comments:
Other Options

On Choice Band sets, Superpower can be used to pressure the likes of Porygon2 and Umbreon.

Checks and Counters

Defensive Walls: Blanket defensive walls like Donphan, Cresselia, Slowbro, and Umbreon are able to avoid a 2HKO from Zygarde-10%'s Choice Band-boosted Thousand Arrows or take a boosted Devastating Drake with appropriate investment and beat it with Earthquake, Ice Beam, or Foul Play. On the flip side, Zygarde-10% can get past these defensive Pokemon with Toxic, entry hazard support, or prior chip damage.

Grass-types: Tangela, Shaymin, Virizion, Tsareena, and Mega Abomasnow can switch into Thousand Arrows and threaten Zygarde-10% with their STAB moves, though Tangela is the only one of them that can also take a Outrage or Devastating Drake on the switch. Mega Abomasnow can reliably revenge kill Zygarde-10% with Ice Shard if it is healthy enough to take an Extreme Speed, while Shaymin can pack Hidden Power Ice to OHKO Zygarde-10%.

Faster Pokemon: Despite Extreme Speed's great neutral coverage and damage output, offensive threats such as Noivern, Salazzle, and Choice Scarf Gardevoir can revenge kill Zygarde-10% if they come safely onto the field. Choice Scarf Tyrantrum is even better at revenge killing Choice Band Zygarde-10%, as it doesn't mind taking an Extreme Speed.

Priority Moves: Since Zygarde-10% has poor defensive stats, it can be easily taken out by priority from Mega Abomasnow, Golisopod, Lycanroc-D, Donphan, and Arcanine with some prior damage, though Lycanroc-D and Donphan are the only ones usually safe from Zygarde-10%'s own Extreme Speed if weakened enough.

Steel- and Fairy-type Pokemon: Although they don't like to come into Thousand Arrows, Steel- and Fairy-types such as Bronzong, Registeel, Metagross, Stakataka, Gardevoir, and Florges can deter Zygarde-10% from using Outrage and beat it should it do so.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Dragon Dance boosts Zygarde-10%'s Attack and Speed to stellar levels, allowing it to outspeed the likes of Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Tyrantrum, and Flygon. Thousand Arrows is a STAB move that can take down Steel- and Fire-types like Registeel, Bronzong, and Ninetales. Outrage is a secondary STAB move against Pokemon that resist Thousand Arrows, such as Shaymin, Virizion, and Golisopod. When paired with Dragonium Z, it can become a powerful nuke to take down defensive behemoths like Milotic, Cresselia, and Slowbro after a boost and some chip damage. Extreme Speed can pick off weakened foes when unboosted and is an option to deal with even faster Pokemon at +1 like Choice Scarf Salazzle and Noivern while also being in a higher priority bracket than other priority moves, such as Golisopod's First Impression and Honchkrow's Sucker Punch.

Set Details

Dragonium Z improves Zygarde-10%'s potential as a cleaner, having great power to deal with most checks after a boost. A Jolly nature with maximum EVs in Attack and Speed is preferred to outspeed the likes of Virizion and Lycanroc when unboosted, but Adamant can be a good option to increase Zygarde-10%'s damage output while still leaving it able to outspeed threats such as Shaymin and Ninetales. Examples of notable KOs that can be reached with an Adamant nature include a guaranteed OHKO against Milotic and Umbreon and a 50% chance to OHKO Donphan after Stealth Rock.

Usage Tips

When dealing with the likes of Milotic or Mandibuzz, Devastating Drake must be used carefully, as the opponent might switch out to another weakened Pokemon to waste its use. Be sure to remove Steel- and Fairy-type Pokemon before locking Zygarde-10% into Outrage, as they can take advantage of it in that state. Try to find setup opportunities against Pokemon that get forced out or can't do much against Zygarde-10%. Be it after sacking another Pokemon or making use of pivoting, Zygarde-10% can be sent out against the likes of Drapion, Arcanine, or Ninetales to set up on a forced switch. Avoid switching Zygarde-10% directly into opposing attacks, since the chip damage will make setting up much more difficult. Ideally, Zygarde-10% might be preserved to set up in late-game situations, unless it needs to revenge kill an opposing Pokemon.

Team Options

Zygarde-10% works great with entry hazard support, especially in the form of Spikes. Roserade, Golisopod, and Accelgor can offer great offensive synergy while stacking Spikes on the field. Knock Off users such as Pangoro, Drapion, and Escavalier are great offensive partners to Zygarde-10%, since they can remove items such as Porygon2's Eviolite and Milotic's Leftovers and weaken checks such as Cresselia, Slowbro, and Uxie, while Zygarde-10% can force out Pokemon like Ninetales and Arcanine. In more offensive teams, dual screens support from Meowstic-M, Uxie, and Electrode can make Zygarde-10%'s setup much easier while also protecting it from most priority moves. Steel-types like Bronzong, Registeel, and Forretress can cover Zygarde-10%'s weaknesses to Ice- and Dragon-type moves while offering hazard support and general defensive utility. Escavalier and Metagross can cover those weaknesses and provide offensive presence and wallbreaking power alongside hazard setting.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Thousand Arrows deals great damage to most neutral targets and forces out offensive threats such as Raikou, Drapion, and Houndoom. Outrage is Zygarde-10%'s secondary STAB move, allowing it to 2HKO most Pokemon that resist Thousand Arrows. Examples include Shaymin, Virizion, and Araquanid. Extreme Speed is a reliable revenge killing measure against faster threats like Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Noivern, weakened Donphan, and Salazzle after prior damage. Toxic is a utility move that allows Zygarde-10% to cripple defensive Pokemon, such as Cresselia, Slowbro, and Tangela, putting them on a timer every time they switch into it. Earthquake's greater damage output, however, can guarantee a 2HKO against Mega Blastoise and offer more damage against various threats without getting locked into Outrage.

Set Details

Choice Band greatly increases Zygarde-10%'s raw power and damage output. A Jolly nature with maximum Attack and Speed investment is needed to outspeed threats such as Virizion and Lycanroc-D. You can run an Adamant nature so that Zygarde-10% can 2HKO Slowbro, Uxie, and Porygon2 with Outrage after Stealth Rock but Adamant fails to outpace Pokemon such as the aforementioned Pokemon.

Usage Tips

Most of the time, Zygarde-10% will use Thousand Arrows due to its great capability of hitting most Pokemon on the tier. Outrage is a great tool to break opposing Pokemon that resist Thousand Arrows such as Shaymin, which can allow Zygarde-10%'s teammates to win the game later on as they are removed from the opposing team. However, be aware of Steel- and Fairy-types that can come into Outrage and knock it out. Against faster Pokemon and setup sweepers, Zygarde-10%'s partners must get these Pokemon weakened enough so Zygarde-10% can revenge kill them or clean with Extreme Speed. Toxic is a great way to give Zygarde-10%'s walls a hard time, since the likes of Slowbro and Cresselia will be forced to recover way more often. Zygarde-10% must be aware of which move it locks itself into, as it can be taken advantage of by opposing Pokemon, especially those that usually carry Protect, such as Bronzong and Registeel.

Team Options

Fighting-types like Machamp, Pangoro, and Toxicroak can be great partners to Zygarde-10% due to their access to Knock Off and Ice-type coverage, which allows them to take on common defensive roadblocks such as Tangela, Cresselia, and Donphan. Drapion is a great partner to Zygarde-10%, as it can trap most Psychic-types with a Choice Band set, such as Slowbro, Cresselia, and Uxie, and beat other checks such as Donphan, Porygon2, and Tangela with its Swords Dance + Waterium Z set. Raikou, Swellow, and Yanmega can offer wallbreaking power and utility with Volt Switch and U-turn, as they can pivot Zygarde-10% in safely against their own checks and counters, such as Registeel, Tyrantrum, and Bronzong. Mega Abomasnow and Vanilluxe greatly appreciate Zygarde-10%'s ability to take out Steel-types, while they can reliably beat Slowbro and Milotic. Setup sweepers such as Barbaracle and Cloyster are great alongside Zygarde-10%, as it can weaken common defensive Pokemon so they can clean the game later on. Roserade, Forretress, and Accelgor can set up Spikes on the field, which makes Zygarde-10%s work easier due to the chip damage its checks take every time they come into the field while Spikes are up.

Diancie.overview: Diancie is an interesting defensive Pokemon in the tier that compresses Stealth Rock with the ability to check Noivern, Arcanine, Goodra, Mega Ampharos, Swellow, and Houndoom thanks to its typing and mixed bulk. Diancie also has an easy time setting up entry hazards against a handful of the tier's removers such as Mandibuzz, Mega Blastoise, and Sigilyph. However, Diancie is completely hopeless against Steel-types like Metagross, Registeel, and Bronzong due to their resistance to its primary attacks alongside their immunity to Toxic, although Earth Power somewhat mitigates this flaw. Diancie also invites some of the most dangerous offensive Pokemon in the metagame like Zygarde-10%, Shaymin, Roserade, and Virizion in due to its typing. Diancie's lack of reliable recovery can also leave it worn down quickly throughout the match, and it can be chipped down by Stealth Rock and Spikes and crippled by poison and burns. Diancie faces competition from other defensive Rock-types like Rhyperior and Gigalith, which both have essential tools to pressure out Steel-types and can also check Salazzle as opposed to Diancie, but Diancie's higher Special Defense and part-Fairy-typing, which allow it to be a more reliable answer to Houndoom and other special attackers, can set it apart.
Diancie.comments:
Other Options

Power Gem can be used to defeat Pokemon such as Sigilyph, but is generally a worse coverage option than Earth Power. Diamond Storm paired with a Sassy nature gives Diancie a stronger attack that can also boost its Defense to toughen it up against physical attackers like Toxicroak and Drapion, but its lower accuracy and low PP compared to Power Gem can be detrimental in long, drawn-out games. Diancie could attempt at sweeping with a Calm Mind + Groundium Z set to bust through Metagross and Registeel, but this set needs to invest into its offensive stats, which makes it less effective defensively. This set is also outclassed by other Calm Mind users like Slowbro, Necrozma, and Raikou. Diancie can stall out foes with Protect and Toxic, but this removes coverage that Diancie often wants for checking Flying- and Fire-types. Shuca Berry is useful on more offensive teams, as Diancie can lure in Nidoqueen and Zygarde-10% and retaliate, but this item is difficult to justify over Leftovers.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Metagross and Escavalier destroy Diancie with their STAB moves. Metagross needs to be wary of Diancie's Earth Power, however. Defensive Steel-types like Bronzong and Registeel completely wall Diancie as well, although the latter fears the rare Calm Mind + Groundium Z set.

Grass-types: Roserade, Shaymin, and Virizion can offensively pressure Diancie with super effective damage, although the latter should be wary of Moonblast. Tsareena can also remove Diancie's entry hazards while pressuring it.

Water-types: Water-types such as Golisopod and Barbaracle are offensive answers to Diancie, while Milotic and Slowbro take a Defensive approach, with the former taking advantage of Toxic by virtue of Marvel Scale.

Ground-types: Donphan can spin away Diancie's entry hazards, while Nidoqueen completely walls any set that isn't using Earth Power. Zygarde-10% and Flygon can revenge kill Diancie after it's chipped, although these two should scout for a potential Shuca Berry.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Moves

Moonblast is Diancie's main attack and is also important for fishing for Special Attack drops against the likes of Dragalge, Mismagius, and Necrozma. Earth Power offers the coverage to damage Nidoqueen, Metagross, and Houndoom super effectively. Toxic can be essential to crippling walls like Slowbro and Cresselia, but Heal Bell is an alternative if the team could use a cleric.

Set Details

A Calm nature boosts Diancie's Special Defense without compromising its power. Clear Body is Diancie's only ability but does have some use in preventing random stat drops from Psychic and Bug Buzz. Normalium Z can be used in tandem with Heal Bell to offer Diancie a one-time full recovery, making it more useful in matches against faster teams; however, Leftovers is generally more consistent and does not take up a Z slot.

Usage Tips

Diancie should set up Stealth Rock as early as possible to deal chip damage and soften up any checks. Diancie should also often be switched in against foes it checks such as Noivern, Goodra, Arcanine, and Houndoom if it's healthy enough in order to stomach their attacks and potentially set up Stealth Rock. Spreading Toxic is not a bad strategy to help wear down defensive switch-ins like Donphan and Slowbro when Stealth Rock is already on the field in order to cripple the opposition and offer its teammates complementary chip damage to soften up the opponent's defenses. Diancie should avoid status if it isn't running Heal Bell, as it greatly hinders its longevity in the match. Diancie will often invite Steel-types, so aggressive doubles to bring in Fire- or Ground-types that prey on these Pokemon or possibly scouting and chipping with Earth Power can work.

Team Options

Diancie fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that require role compression to round out the rest of the team. Roserade, Virizion, and Shaymin are all offensive Grass-types that greatly appreciate Diancies ability to check Fire- and Flying-types. Ground- and Fire-types such as Zygarde-10%, Donphan, Salazzle, Arcanine, and Houndoom can offensively pressure the Steel-types that Diancie struggles with. Slowbro forms a strong defensive core with Diancie due to it checking Zygarde-10% and other Ground-types and its high Defense that complements Diancie's Special Defense. Entry hazards can chip Diancie fairly quickly if they're stacked up, so removal from Mandibuzz, Mega Blastoise, and Tsareena can be essential to keeping Diancie healthy.

Hoopa.overview: Hoopa appears to be a threatening offensive Pokemon, since it sports a good STAB combination and the highest Special Attack stat in RU. Unfortunately, its Speed and Defense are incredibly lacking, which allows it to be revenge killed and Pursuit trapped easily by Pokemon such as Golisopod, Zygarde-10%, and Drapion. Hoopa's defensive typing also leaves it extremely vulnerable to Pokemon with Dark-type coverage moves like Donphan and Mega Blastoise, which makes it a terrible spinblocker. Mismagius often gives Hoopa immense competition thanks to its much better Speed tier and ability to threaten other playstyles besides balance and stall.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Hoopa can attempt to take advantage of more passive Pokemon such as Registeel and Bronzong by setting up a Substitute and boosting with Nasty Plot. Once Substitute is broken, however, it becomes incredibly easy to revenge kill due to its horrible defensive typing and pitiful Defense. Mismagius is a much better pick for most teams due to its superior Speed and defensive utility.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee can be a passable option as a fast special attacker thanks to its high Speed tier and good coverage. It can revenge kill an assortment of offensive threats, including Choice Band Zygarde-10%, Nasty Plot Salazzle, Noivern, and Virizion, and has Quiver Dance to beat Choice Scarf users that would otherwise revenge kill it. Ribombee also has a few appealing support options in Sticky Web, Tailwind, and Defog, which could potentially fill holes in a team. Unfortunately, several large weaknesses prevent Ribombee from being very common in the metagame. While Bug / Fairy isn't a terrible defensive typing, Ribombee's absurd frailty means it can only switch into passive walls and weak resisted hits. Anything remotely strong, even resisted, will likely 2HKO it. While fast, it still is outsped by every relevant Choice Scarf user when unboosted, and most of them will OHKO it as long as Stealth Rock is up. Priority users such as Machamp and Zygarde-10% can also prove troublesome. Having average Special Attack for a sweeper forces Ribombee to use its Z-Move to revenge kill prominent threats like Virizion, leaving it depleted for potential future sweeps. Finally, common special tanks on bulky teams like Registeel, Snorlax, and Bronzong can weather even boosted attacks, making Ribombee struggle to successfully dent holes in such teams.
Ribombee.comments:
Other Options

A Sticky Web lead set with Focus Sash is usable, but Sticky Web offense is too unreliable for this set to warrant much attention. Tailwind can give wallbreakers a couple turns to wreak havoc. Defog can be used if you desperately need hazard removal and can't fit it anywhere else, but Ribombee is horrible at removing because of its Stealth Rock weakness and inability to adequately threaten most hazard users.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types easily punish Ribombee for attempting to sweep too early and can come in on most of its coverage options. Alolan Marowak and Arcanine get chances to fire off powerful attacks while Ninetales can set up Nasty Plot.

Steel-types: Steel-types wall Ribombee's STAB moves, with most also having the bulk to take boosted Bug Buzz or Hidden Power Fire comfortably. Bronzong and Registeel can do so while retaliating with STAB attacks or Toxic.

Special Tanks: Ribombee's average Special Attack means that walls such as Snorlax and Porygon2 will take its hits easily and be free to either attack it or use Toxic and stall it.

Faster Threats: While it has an amazing natural Speed tier, Choice Scarf users such as Gardevoir, Roserade, and Salazzle can revenge kill any unboosted Ribombee, and priority users like Zygarde-10%, Medicham, Pangoro, and Golisopod will beat it regardless with a little chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Moves

U-turn is great for pivoting out of some sturdier Fairy-type answers such as Registeel. Although Sticky Web on a Choice Specs set may seem odd, it's great for slowing down opposing teams, and Ribombee's offensive presence yields plenty of opportunities to set it up. Psychic improves Ribombee's ability to act as a revenge killer, letting it remove Pokemon like Salazzle. It also lets Ribombee hit Pokemon like Nidoqueen and Roserade. Sticky Web or Psychic can be dropped for Hidden Power Fire, which allows Ribombee to remove weakened Steel-types. However, Bug Buzz already hits Steel-types such as Bronzong and Metagross, so Hidden Power Fire is commonly inefficient.

Set Details

A Timid nature allows Ribombee to outpace Pokemon like Noivern, Zygarde-10%, and Raikou. Shield Dust lets Ribombee avoid secondary effects such as burn from Scald.

Usage Tips

Utilize Ribombee's defensive typing to pivot into and check attackers such as Synthesis Virizion, Zygarde-10%, Shaymin, and weakened Mega Blastoise. However, give such threats as few turns as possible, as Ribombee's lackluster bulk prevents it from switching in more than one or two times. Ribombee's somewhat lackluster Special Attack prevents it from being able to make headway against Pokemon such as Registeel, Milotic, and Porygon2. So, instead of attacking them, use U-turn on the switch in to gain momentum and give free turns to teammates. Set up Sticky Web on forced switches to support slower teammates. For example, if up against a Pokemon such as Virizion or Tsareena, take advantage of the free turn by setting up Sticky Web. However, use Sticky Web with caution to avoid giving opposing setup sweepers like Barbaracle free turns.

Team Options

Choice Specs Ribombee is best used on bulky offense teams that really appreciate its defensive typing allowing it to be a one- or two-time switch-in to some of the tier's bigger threats, mainly Zygarde-10%, Virizion lacking Stone Edge, and Shaymin. Slow, powerful wallbreakers such as Guts Machamp, Choice Band Tyrantrum, and Pangoro appreciate Ribombee's ability to give them free turns through U-turn and, especially, Sticky Web, which lets them outpace checks such as Mega Blastoise. They also break down many of Ribombee's checks and counters, making it much easier to clean up late-game with Ribombee. Sticky Web is also fantastic support for setup sweepers, as it allows teammates like Virizion to beat Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Gardevoir and Shaymin and Rock Polish Tyrantrum to outpace Choice Scarf Salazzle. Tyrantrum also makes use of Ribombee's weakness to Fire- and Poison-types to set up.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Quiver Dance allows Ribombee to boost its Special Attack and Speed to high levels and buff its Special Defense to something respectable. Moonblast is Ribombee's strongest STAB move, possessing strong neutral coverage. Psychic prevents common Poison-types such as Nidoqueen and Salazzle from walling Ribombee. Bug Buzz is used as a strong STAB option and to hit threats like Shaymin, Cresselia, Metagross, and Bronzong harder. Hidden Power Fire can be used instead to hits the numerous Steel-types in RU that resist Bug Buzz, including Escavalier, Klinklang, and Forretress.

Set Details

252 Special Attack EVs let Ribombee hit as hard as possible. 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow unboosted Ribombee to outspeed threats like Noivern and Zygarde-10%, and even the fastest Choice Scarf users like Salazzle after a boost. Fairium Z lets Ribombee break through some naturally bulky Fairy-neutral checks like Gardevoir and Diancie. Shield Dust prevents secondary effects from attacks that Ribombee might tank while boosting like Milotic's Scald.

Usage Tips

Remove priority users such as Arcanine, Zygarde-10%, Golisopod, Medicham, and Mega Glalie before attempting to boost, as they can quickly cut a sweep short. Try to preserve Ribombee's health early-game so that it has a better chance to survive a hit when it needs to boost. You should avoid bringing it in with direct switches, but you can still use this set to revenge kill if necessary. Weakening Ribombee's checks and counters to the point where Twinkle Tackle can KO them will allow you to sweep more easily. Keeping entry hazards away for Ribombee allows it to revenge kill early- and mid-game without removing its ability to sweep late-game.

Team Options

Ground-types such as Nidoqueen, Seismitoad, and Rhyperior can both threaten Steel-types and keep Stealth Rock on the field to increase Ribombee's chance of sweeping. Fighting-types such as Medicham, Virizion, and Bewear can break holes in special tanks like Snorlax, Registeel, and Porygon2, creating chances for Ribombee to sweep the rest of your opponent's team. Roserade and Gardevoir are interesting teammate options on hyper offense teams, as with Sleep Powder and Memento they can give Ribombee chances to set up freely. Mega Blastoise synergizes very well with Ribombee, providing both good coverage and hazard removal. Pursuit trappers like Drapion and Sneasel can remove troublesome Ribombee checks like Bronzong and Alolan Marowak.

Lycanroc-Dusk.overview: Due to its access to Tough Claws, Swords Dance and a powerful exclusive Z-Move in Splintered Stormshards, Lycanroc-D can be a fearsome wallbreaker that is able to open holes in defensive teams, crippling or KOing the likes of Bewear, Bronzong, and Milotic. Lycanroc-D also has unique access to Rock-type priority in Accelerock, which lets it revenge kill the likes of Swellow and Salazzle. It can also run Sucker Punch to hit the likes of Choice Scarf Flygon, Choice Scarf Medicham, and Zygarde-10% neutrally. Unfortunately, Lycanroc-D relies on low-Base Power moves such as Fire Fang and Drill Run to break through some of its checks that need to be weakened before it is able to sweep. Due to its poor bulk, it doesn't offer much defensive utility, being unable to set up properly even against Fire-type Pokemon such as Ninetales, which Lycanroc-D can't take despite resisting them, due to their additional coverage. Lycanroc-D also cannot set up against some of the most relevant defensive Pokemon in the tier, including Shuca Berry Metagross, Milotic, and Foul Play Mandibuzz. Another problem is the amount of support Lycanroc-D needs to work; although it can be very strong after a Swords Dance, it usually cannot set up properly without taking a big hit, needing support from pivoting, dual screens, or Memento to set up safely and stay healthy.
Lycanroc-Dusk.comments:
Other Options

Crunch can be used to hit Bronzong harder, but it is outclassed by Fire Fang and Drill Run's range of targets. Lycanroc-D can opt for a suicide lead set with Focus Sash, Stealth Rock, Taunt, Accelerock, and Endeavor as an option for hyper offensive teams, but it is a suboptimal set due to the availability of a better suicide lead in Forretress.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Although Lycanroc-D has the coverage to threaten them, Bronzong, Metagross, and Steelix can usually take an unboosted hit and retaliate with their super-effective STAB moves.

Fighting-types: Virizion, Bewear, Passimian, and Pangoro can take any unboosted hit and defeat Lycanroc-D with their STAB attacks, usually recovering some HP in the process.

Ground-types: The likes of Rhyperior and Donphan can take any hit from Lycanroc-D and set up Stealth Rock, remove entry hazards with Defog, or OHKO it with their STAB moves.

Faster Attackers: Choice Scarf Tyrantrum, Choice Scarf Flygon, and Zygarde-10% outspeed Lycanroc-D and can OHKO it, but the latter two are OHKOed by a boosted Life Orb Sucker Punch.

Priority Moves: Choice Band Golisopod can revenge kill Lycanroc-D in a single blow with First Impression due to its higher priority than Sucker Punch or Accelerock. Machamp, Medicham, and Pangoro can revenge kill Lycanroc-D after Stealth Rock damage with Bullet Punch.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Swords Dance allows Lycanroc-D to punch holes into defensive cores with Stone Edge or Splintered Stormshards. Stone Edge is Lycanroc-D's main STAB move, 2HKOing the likes of Milotic, Bewear, and Cresselia after a Swords Dance boost when boosted by a Life Orb. It also can turn into Splintered Stormshards when Lycanroc-D is holding a Lycanium Z, which allows it to OHKO them right away after Stealth Rock damage. Fire Fang lets Lycanroc-D deal with Bronzong after a Swords Dance boost while also doing good damage to Bewear. Drill Run is an option over Fire Fang to guarantee an OHKO on Pokemon such as Registeel and Nidoqueen while also offering greater damage against the likes of Rhyperior and non Shuca Berry Metagross. Sucker Punch is Lycanroc-D's main form of priority, allowing it to OHKO Choice Scarf Flygon, Gardevoir, and Zygarde-10% after a boost. Accelerock is a STAB priority option that allows Lycanroc-D to beat Noivern when unboosted after Stealth Rock damage as well as deal with Salazzle and Swellow better.

Set Details

Maximum investment in Speed and Attack with a Jolly nature lets Lycanroc-D be as fast and as powerful as it can. A Life Orb is the main item option to increase Lycanroc-D's power, which allows Sucker Punch and Accelerock to achieve essential KOs, such as unboosted Accelerock KOing Noivern after Stealth Rock, unboosted Accelerock OHKOing Salazzle, and boosted Sucker Punch OHKOing the likes of Choice Scarf Gardevoir and Zygarde-10%. Lycanium Z is an option to beat the likes of Milotic, Cresselia, Bewear, and Bronzong with Splintered Stormshards after some chip damage. Tough Claws is Lycanroc-D's only ability and is essential to Fire Fang and Sucker Punch's power.

Usage Tips

Avoid being statused by the likes of Porygon2's Thunder Wave and Choice Scarf Gardevoirs Will-O-Wisp, since they cripple Lycanroc-D and its ability to fire off Life Orb-boosted attacks. Use Swords Dance on forced switches against foes like Ninetales and Salazzle. Despite Lycanroc-D's poor bulk, it can still set up freely against Pokemon like Noivern and Salazzle. Before sending Lycanroc-D in to sweep, make sure to weaken some of its switch-ins, such as Rhyperior, Steelix, and Bewear.

Team Options

Pivoting is essential with Lycanroc-D, since it has problems switching into virtually anything. U-turn or Volt Switch support from the likes of Uxie, Flygon, Raikou, and Mega Ampharos is very appreciated. Memento support from the likes of Uxie, Choice Scarf Gardevoir, and Mismagius is also nice, since it lets Lycanroc-D set up safely against almost anything that comes into field. Wallbreakers such as Ninetales, Bewear, and Zygarde-10% make Lycanroc-D's life easier, since they can weaken Lycanroc-D's checks so it can clean up later in the game. Pokemon that resist Water-, Ground-, and Fighting-type moves are essential when running Lycanroc-D. Shaymin, Virizion, and TauntTox Mandibuzz are good options that can help break cores and offer utility options. It's nice to pair Lycanroc-D with offensive Pokemon that take advantage of some of the defensive threats that Lycanroc-D can break through, such as Choice Scarf Gardevoir, Tyrantrum, and Zygarde-10%. Support like dual screens from Uxie and Meowstic and Spikes from Mega Glalie and Roserade is appreciated, as it allows Lycanroc-D to set up more safely and wear down its checks.

Araquanid.overview: Araquanid stands out as one of the most viable setters of Sticky Web thanks to its offensive presence and matchup against key entry hazard removers such as Mega Blastoise, Donphan, and Xatu. A great ability in Water Bubble, a solid Special Defense stat, and resistances to key types in the tier such as Ground, Fighting, and Water also make it capable of handling common threats in the metagame such as Nidoqueen, Slowbro, and Houndoom. However, Araquanid is quite slow and has pitiful physical bulk. A weakness to Stealth Rock also hampers its longevity by quite a bit. Its non-Water-type moves are not very powerful, and thus its movepool contains very few viable attacking options. Lastly, it faces competition as a Sticky Web setter from Ribombee and Galvantula, which are much faster and have similar offensive presence, and the former can also beat other entry hazard removers such as Tsareena that Araquanid has trouble with. Their higher Speed stats also help them fare a bit better against Mega Blastoise.
Araquanid.comments:
Other Options

A set utilizing Spider Web / Liquidation / Leech Life or Toxic / Rest with a Splash Plate or Metronome can be useful, as it can safely remove certain defensive threats in the tier such as Slowbro, Milotic, and Tangela from the match to clear the way for teammates. However, this set isn't popular because one of its main targets, Milotic, is not common enough to justify using and Substitute + Toxic can already handle most of its other targets. More offensive sets without Sticky Web, such as a Choice Band set, can seem like good options considering the power of Araquanid's STAB Liquidation, but these sets are often outclassed by Golisopod, which has access to priority moves and stronger non-Water-type moves. These sets also have trouble breaking through bulky Pokemon that resist Water.

Checks and Counters

Water-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Noivern, Shaymin, and Virizion can usually take a hit from Araquanid and hit back hard, with Noivern OHKOing it occasionally. More niche Water-resistant or -immune Pokemon such as Milotic and Seismitoad can also work well, with the former even having Refresh to nullify Toxic.

Faster Physical Attackers: Pokemon such as Tyrantrum, Toxicroak, and Bewear prey on Araquanid's poor physical bulk and usually don't take much from any of its moves. Notably, Toxicroak is immune to Araquanid's Water-type STAB moves thanks to Dry Skin, resists Leech Life, and is unaffected by Toxic.

Flying-type Pokemon: Pokemon such as Noivern, Yanmega, and Swellow, while unable to switch into Araquanid, can easily revenge kill it with strong STAB moves. Mantine is a more defensive option that is also immune to Water-type attacks thanks to Water Absorb.

Electric-type Pokemon: Raikou outspeeds Araquanid and can OHKO it with Stealth Rock up; it can 2HKO Araquanid otherwise. Mega Ampharos is a more niche option but also resists Araquanid's Liquidation and doesn't even need Stealth Rock to OHKO Araquanid.

Residual Damage: Entry hazards such as Spikes and Stealth Rock can wear down Araquanid quickly due to its lack of reliable recovery and weakness to the latter. While it's immune to burns, it is very much vulnerable to Toxic because of said lack of recovery.

sets.name: Sticky Web
sets.description:
Moves

Araquanid makes for a good setter of Sticky Web thanks to its good power and solid defensive attributes. Liquidation is a strong STAB move capable of easily 2HKOing common entry hazard removers such as Donphan and Sigilyph. Magic Coat is capable of bouncing back status moves that can disrupt Araquanid and its team, particularly Taunt. Mirror Coat is used in the last slot to take advantage of Araquanid's naturally good special bulk and to beat Mega Blastoise.

Set Details

Water Bubble boosts the power of Liquidation. Splash Plate complements this, giving Araquanid a significant offensive presence. An Adamant nature and maximum Attack investment increase Araquanid's damage output further still. Maximum Speed investment allows Araquanid to outspeed defensive Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Vaporeon. Once Sticky Web is up, it can also outspeed Florges.

Usage Tips

Sticky Web should be set when the foe switches out, the opponent's entry hazard remover has fainted, or the current matchup is generally in Araquanid's favor. The threat of Liquidation can also be used to pressure the opponent into giving Araquanid chances to set up Sticky Web. Unlike other setters of Sticky Web such as Ribombee and Galvantula, Araquanid can more easily set it up again if it had been removed earlier in the match thanks to its bulk. Said bulk also allows Araquanid can to switch into entry hazard removers in the tier such as Mega Blastoise and Donphan, and while Knock Off from the latter can do quite a bit of damage to Araquanid, it resists Earthquake and Ice Shard. Magic Coat is best utilized when you predict the opposing Pokemon will use a status move, particularly Stealth Rock from Pokemon like Registeel and Metagross, and Toxic from the likes of Mandibuzz. Mirror Coat is best utilized against special attackers such as Ribombee, Salazzle, and especially Mega Blastoise, which can be 2HKOed by its own reflected Dark Pulse.

Team Options

Slow but powerful wallbreakers such as Tyrantrum, Honchkrow, Bewear, and Machamp heavily benefit from the Speed drops that Sticky Web gives to the opponent's team. To make Rapid Spin usage a bit more difficult, spinblockers such as Mismagius can be utilized as partners to this Araquanid set. Similarly, Pokemon capable of handling common Defog users such as Passimian and Taunt users such as Honchkrow and Mismagius are good partners to this Araquanid set. Additional entry hazard setters such as Roserade and Metagross can complement both Araquanid and other teammates by giving them additional wallbreaking power. These two Pokemon also benefit a lot from Sticky Web.

sets.name: Substitute + Toxic
sets.description:
Moves

The combination of Substitute and Toxic allows Araquanid to effectively stall out common threats such as Slowbro, Mega Blastoise, and Mandibuzz. Liquidation serves as a strong STAB move backed by Araquanid's Water Bubble ability and is capable of hitting a wide range of Pokemon in the RU metagame neutrally. Leech Life is mainly used to hit Grass-types such as Shaymin, Tangela, and Mega Sceptile; the health recovery from the move is a bonus. Protect can be used over Leech Life to gain free Toxic damage and Leftovers recovery for a turn. However, this tends to leave Araquanid walled by Grass-types as a result.

Set Details

68 EVs in Speed allow Araquanid to outspeed Pokemon with base 50 Speed such as Registeel and Donphan. Maximum Attack investment makes Araquanid hit as hard as possible. Leftovers offsets the health reduction Substitute provides over time, and 188 HP EVs allow it to regain more health from Leftovers. It also works well alongside Leech Life to provide additional healing capability.

Usage Tips

Use Substitute when you expect a bulky Pokemon such as Slowbro or Mandibuzz to come into play, and then use Toxic to attempt to outstall them. Araquanid's typing should be utilized for opportunities to switch in on Pokemon like Nidoqueen, Bronzong, and Mega Blastoise. Liquidation's higher power via Water Bubble and better coverage mean that it is usually the more reliable attacking move over Leech Life. When the Pokemon you are trying to outstall resists Liquidation, you should use Toxic instead to apply better pressure. If Protect is used in the last slot, use it when you expect the foe to break Araquanid's Substitute, or as a way to scout for potential moves that may threaten Araquanid.

Team Options

Offensive Pokemon such as Metagross, Machamp, and Houndoom appreciate Araquanid's ability to wear down bulky threats such as Slowbro and Mandibuzz. Cleaners such as Zygarde-10%, Salazzle, and Swellow can take advantage of Araquanid's ability to open holes in the opponent's team. More physically defensive Pokemon such as Rhyperior, Slowbro, and Forretress can help out with Araquanid's weakness to strong physical moves. Lastly, entry hazard removers such as Sigilyph, Donphan, and Tsareena help with Araquanid's vulnerability to Stealth Rock and Spikes, allowing it to set up more Substitutes throughout a match.

Salazzle.overview: In a sea of lower-tier Fire-types, Salazzle stands out as one of the most lethal among them and one of the most powerful RU Pokemon. Its excellent STAB combination, great Speed, and access to Nasty Plot give it the means to pose as a threatening sweeper to every playstyle, and its great typing makes up for its minuscule defenses by granting it crucial 4x resistances and a Toxic immunity, which allow it to set up on Pokemon like Florges, Roserade, Registeel, and single-attack or Choice-locked Escavalier. Salazzle's defensive typing serves other purposes as well by diluting the threat of Toxic Spikes and letting it serve as an offensive check to Chlorophyll Venusaur and Synthesis Virizion. Salazzle is also a notable user of Z-Moves, using its Acid Downpour to its fullest by melting through a slew of tenacious specially defensive Pokemon such as Snorlax, Diancie, Milotic, and Cresselia with minimal support. Salazzle's frailty and Stealth Rock weakness result in it being a tad too easy to revenge kill with priority such as Sucker Punch or any ordinary Choice Scarf user, however. Salazzle's lack of bulk also restricts setup opportunities to forced switches and specific targets, and even then, due to Salazzle's limited coverage options, it requires additional support to break through the likes of Gigalith.
Salazzle.comments:
Other Options

Dragon Pulse allows Nasty Plot Salazzle to get more damage on Goodra and Dragalge but is otherwise not as useful as Hidden Power Ice. Knock Off can be used as Nasty Plot's fourth move so that Salazzle can cripple its defensive checks prior to setting up. Knock Off can also cripple potential switch-ins like Choice Scarf Tyrantrum, giving Salazzle an easier time sweeping late-game. Encore can enable setup versus entry hazard setters and removers, ease Sucker Punch mind games, and turn the tables on opposing setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Raikou, but it is not particularly reliable. Substitute can be used to dodge Sucker Punch, evade Thunder Wave, and make Salazzle harder to revenge kill, but losing coverage makes Salazzle much easier to counter. Toxic + Hidden Power Ice can be run in the last two slots on Salazzle's Choice Scarf set to hit threats like Flygon for more damage as well as cripple switch-ins like Porygon2 and Mandibuzz, but should only be run if Barbaracle is covered well by Salazzle's teammates.

Checks and Counters

Gigalith: Gigalith is by far Salazzle's best counter due to its incredible special bulk and lack of exploitative weaknesses. Gigalith is capable of taking hits from a +2 Salazzle and KOing it back while almost always outlasting it due to its ability to set sand and Stealth Rock up to wear Salazzle down quickly.

STAB-resistant Pokemon: Dragalge, Aerodactyl, Choice Scarf Flygon, and Choice Scarf Tyrantrum resist Salazzle's Poison-type attacks and are capable of revenge killing it in the case of Tyrantrum, Aerodactyl, and Flygon or defensively checking it in the case of Dragalge.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Cresselia, Porygon2, Snorlax, and Assault Vest Slowking are all capable of taking a hit from full health and dealing massive damage back or outright crippling Salazzle, although prior chip damage can allow Salazzle to muscle through them with +2 Acid Downpour.

Priority Users and Faster Pokemon: Priority users such as Golisopod, Arcanine, and Honchkrow are capable of picking Salazzle off with their respective priority moves, whereas faster Pokemon such as Swellow, Noivern, weather sweepers, and just about any Choice Scarf user revenge kill Salazzle with ease.

sets.name: Special Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

Nasty Plot gives Salazzle the necessary power to break through a variety of walls, including Umbreon and Porygon2. Fire Blast complements Sludge Wave well and is used to KO Registeel at +2. Sludge Wave targets Water- and Dragon-types. Hidden Power Grass keeps Rhyperior, Seismitoad, and Gastrodon from checking Salazzle. Hidden Power Ice is an alternative that KOes Flygon and Zygarde-10% as well as pressuring Dragalge, but the former two can beat Salazzle through Choice Scarf or Extreme Speed anyway. Using Taunt is another option that allows Salazzle to shut down passive Thunder Wave users and Pyukumuku.

Set Details

Poisonium Z is by far Salazzle's best item, as +2 Acid Downpour allows it to OHKO Diancie, Mega Blastoise, and Milotic as well as Snorlax and Cresselia after two switches into Stealth Rock. In addition, Poisonium Z allows Salazzle to more safely set up on passive Knock Off users and gives it the means to break through Prankster Encore. Life Orb can be used if another Z-Move user is more important to your team, and the initial power makes Salazzle's job as a revenge killer a bit easier, but Poisonium Z should always be the first choice due to the significance of the KOs it gets.

The 8 HP EVs prevent Salazzle from being 3HKOed by Umbreon's Foul Play. Oblivious is the more useful ability, as it allows Salazzle to safely set up against Taunt users, and Corrosion simply isn't useful when Salazzle can only inflict poison 10% of the time with Sludge Wave.

Usage Tips

There are only a few offensive Pokemon that Salazzle sets up on, but several Grass-types and defensive Pokemon, including Florges, Roserade, Registeel, and Umbreon, are easy enough to take advantage of. Aside from these Pokemon, Salazzle can be used to revenge kill threats such as Escavalier, Virizion, and Shaymin or even set up on them if a switch is anticipated. Salazzle should only be brought in when a teammate faints to revenge kill or if it's given the proper support with Volt Switch or U-turn users such as Mega Ampharos and Noivern.

Team Options

Defog support from the likes of Mandibuzz is imperative, as Salazzle being at full health allows it to withstand many important attacks it otherwise wouldn't, including Cresselia's Psychic and two of Porygon2's Thunderbolt. Rapid Spin users such as Mega Blastoise and Donphan can provide similar support and work better on offensive teams, but aren't as consistent as Defoggers with reliable recovery. Pivots such as Noivern can use U-turn to bring Salazzle in against Pokemon it sets up on.

Choice Specs Gardevoir and Salazzle share answers in Cresselia and Gigalith, so they can soften up each other's checks. Swellow, Honchkrow, and Yanmega share checks with Salazzle and can make good partners, since Salazzle and any one of the three can wear down these counters for one of them to sweep.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Fire Blast is Salazzle's main STAB move, allowing it to beat Pokemon such as Escavalier, Bewear, and Registeel and hit most Pokemon that don't resist Fire very hard. Sludge Wave allows Salazzle to hit Fairy-types and some Pokemon that are able to take Fire Blast, and it can be used if there's no need to risk a miss with Fire Blast. Hidden Power Grass allows Salazzle to KO Barbaracle and 2HKO specially defensive Rhyperior after Stealth Rock or slight chip damage. Dragon Pulse lets Salazzle hit other setup sweepers and switch-ins like Flygon and Dragalge. Hidden Power Ground is an option to revenge kill opposing Salazzle while still hitting Barbaracle hard.

Set Details

Choice Scarf allows Salazzle to outspeed and revenge kill a lot of threats, including Flygon, Venusaur, Swellow, Barbaracle, Noivern, and Cloyster. 252 EVs in Speed allow Salazzle to outspeed Pokemon such as +1 Zygarde-10% and +2 Naughty Cloyster, while 252 in Special Attack make Salazzle hit as hard as possible. A Timid nature is used to outspeed Modest Venusaur in sun, +2 Naive Cloyster, and +2 Barbaracle.

Usage Tips

This Salazzle set should be used to revenge kill or to clean a game once its checks are weakened enough. Thanks to its Speed and great STAB combination, Choice Scarf Salazzle can revenge kill a lot of Pokemon most other Choice Scarf users can't such as Choice Scarf Flygon, Venusaur in sun, Choice Scarf Shaymin, +2 Barbaracle, and +2 Cloyster. While Salazzle can be brought in on resisted moves such as Florges's Moonblast, it usually doesn't want to take unnecessary damage; it should only come in through a free switch or slow U-turn.

Team Options

This set is useful on offensive or balanced teams that need a check to Pokemon such as Shell Smash Cloyster and Rock Polish Tyrantrum. Defog and Rapid Spin support from Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Donphan, and Mega Blastoise allows Salazzle to come in more often. Pokemon that can set entry hazards such as Golisopod and Registeel can be helpful, as they let Salazzle clean a game or revenge kill opposing Pokemon more easily. Strong wallbreakers such as Swords Dance Bewear, Life Orb Shaymin, and Choice Specs Gardevoir can help weaken Salazzle's checks to give it an easier time cleaning up, while Salazzle can help by weakening Registeel and Metagross, which can make it easier for those wallbreakers to spam their STAB moves.

Bewear.overview: Bewear differentiates itself from other Fighting-type wallbreakers with its defensive presence; its solid bulk combined with Fluffy allows Bewear to switch into physically offensive threats such as Golisopod, Tyrantrum, and Drapion. Bewear also sports an amazing Attack stat and a boosting option in Swords Dance to punch sizable holes in any Pokemon that doesn't resist its STAB combination. Unfortunately, Bewear's lacking Speed and Special Defense and Fluffy giving it an additional Fire-type weakness mean that it rarely gets the opportunity to sweep and invites in faster threats such as Salazzle, Mega Blastoise, and Necrozma. Bewear can also be worn down quickly by repeatedly switching into resisted attacks and entry hazards, Toxic damage, and recoil from Double-Edge. It can mitigate this somewhat by running Drain Punch, however. Despite its unique defensive traits, Bewear faces heavy competition from other Fighting-types in RU such as Machamp, Passimian, and Hariyama, as they all sport superior coverage options, Speed tiers, and Special Defense.
Bewear.comments:
Other Options

Bulk Up alongside Substitute and Leftovers can make Bewear more difficult to take down with physical attacks and can punish passive Pokemon like Bronzong and Registeel, but it loses out on the raw power of Swords Dance and a Z-Move. Taunt can also harass defensive Pokemon by preventing status and recovery, but it requires sacrificing a coverage move or Swords Dance.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Bewear's mediocre Speed and lacking Special Defense leave it vulnerable to getting revenge killed by Pokemon such as Salazzle, Noivern, Mega Blastoise, and Roserade. However, these Pokemon struggle to safely come in against Bewear.

Psychic-types: Bulkier Psychic-types such as Slowbro and Cresselia are capable of pivoting into most, if not all, of Bewear's attacks safely, only taking notable damage from boosted Normal-type attacks. Gardevoir can use Trace to copy Fluffy, which allows it to switch into any attack other than Breakneck Blitz. Other Psychic-types like Necrozma, Sigilyph, and Espeon can threaten out Bewear easily and can attempt to pivot into Fighting-type moves, but they risk being KOed by other attacks.

Ghost-types: Although few and far between, Ghost-types such as Mismagius, Palossand, and Alolan Marowak can put Bewear in poor positions, as they can only be hit by weaker coverage options. They can also set up freely if Choice Band Bewear mistakenly locks itself into a STAB move.

Residual Damage: If not running Drain Punch, Bewear is vulnerable to getting chipped down by entry hazards, Toxic, Double-Edge recoil, and resisted attacks from Pokemon like Golisopod, Lycanroc-D, and Metagross.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Moves

Double-Edge is Bewear's strongest Normal-type STAB attack, with recoil as its only drawback. Superpower scores easier KOs against Pokemon like Diancie, Bronzong, and Stealth Rock Metagross after a boost. Shadow Claw allows Bewear to hit Ghost-types such as Mismagius, Palossand, and Alolan Marowak. Drain Punch is not as strong as Superpower, but it can let Bewear heal itself after taking damage from entry hazards, resisted attacks, or Double-Edge recoil.

Set Details

An Adamant nature gives Bewear the most wallbreaking power possible, but a Jolly nature can be used to outpace certain variants of Mantine and Metagross. Normalium Z powers up Double-Edge into Breakneck Blitz, which does not inflict recoil damage and allows Bewear to OHKO bulkier Pokemon like Cresselia, Slowbro, and Mandibuzz after a boost. Silk Scarf is a viable alternative if a Z-Crystal is being used elsewhere, as it gives Double-Edge more consistent power and can allow unboosted Double-Edge to potentially OHKO Florges after Stealth Rock damage. Fluffy is an excellent ability that eases setup while also allowing Bewear to actively check certain physical threats such as Barbaracle and Tyrantrum, although it leaves Bewear threatened out by most Fire-types like Salazzle.

Usage Tips

Thanks to Fluffy, Bewear can easily come in against physically offensive Pokemon like Barbaracle, Golisopod, and Rhyperior. It can also be brought in safely with the help of a pivot or after a teammate has fainted. Once in battle, Bewear can begin wallbreaking early- and mid-game or even sweep late-game, assuming all of its checks and counters have been dealt with. Fluffy can also allow Bewear to tank moves such as Virizion's Close Combat if needed, but don't let Bewear take too much damage if it is needed to check threats like Snorlax long-term. Bewear should begin setting up with Swords Dance after it has forced out the foe; then, it can threaten bulkier switch-ins such as Slowbro, Cresselia, and Donphan with its Z-Move. However, if a more offensive check like Noivern, Gardevoir, or Nidoqueen is expected to switch in, attacking immediately, even with Breakneck Blitz, can heavily dent or KO these threats and make Bewear much harder to revenge kill. Ghost-types can switch into either STAB move with no issue, so predicting this play with Shadow Claw can open up Bewear to use its stronger STAB attacks.

Team Options

Stealth Rock support from Pokemon like Metagross, Registeel, and Rhyperior assists in many of Bewear's KOs, and these Pokemon can also alleviate Bewear's weakness to Fairy-, Flying-, and Fire-type Pokemon. Bewear can often struggle with Psychic-types such as Cresselia and Gardevoir, as they handle Superpower easily and can tank unboosted Normal-type moves, so partners such as Mismagius, Houndoom, and Drapion can assist Bewear by taking advantage of Psychic-types as well as Ghost-types. Houndoom and Drapion further assist Bewear with Pursuit. Pokemon like Shaymin and Ribombee can threaten physical sponges like Donphan and Tangela and bait in Registeel and certain Rock-types, which can give Bewear an opening to wallbreak. The former also provides Healing Wish support, which can give Bewear another chance to wallbreak if it has taken too much damage early-game. Bewear's vulnerability to many faster threats such as Salazzle, Noivern, and Mega Blastoise means that it appreciates partners such as Aerodactyl, Tyrantrum, and Mega Sceptile, which are capable of offensively checking such Pokemon. Cleaners like Zygarde-10% and Lycanroc-D are capable of capitalizing on Bewear's ability to wear down or remove Pokemon like Donphan and Golisopod. Pivots such as Flygon, Noivern, and Raikou can safely bring Bewear into battle so it can begin wallbreaking.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Moves

Return is a fairly powerful Normal-type option with no drawbacks, but Double-Edge guarantees the 2HKO versus Slowbro and the OHKO against Florges and bulkier Noivern variants at the cost of inflicting recoil. Superpower is Bewear's strongest Fighting-type STAB option with the most reliable damage output, and the stat drops from using the move are often not a big hindrance, as Bewear is likely to switch out after getting a KO regardless. Shadow Claw enables Bewear to avoid getting walled by Ghost-types such as Mismagius and Alolan Marowak. Drain Punch gives Bewear a Fighting-type option that doesn't lower its stats, and it can also keep Bewear healthy in order to tank more hits. Facade can also be used to let Bewear be threatening even after a Scald burn, and it can punish bulkier foes for afflicting Bewear with Toxic.

Set Details

An Adamant nature maximizes Bewear's damage output, with Jolly only being useful for outpacing a few Pokemon like Mantine and Jolly Pangoro. Choice Band gives Bewear great immediate power and capitalizes on its spammable STAB combination. Fluffy enables Bewear to check and threaten out more physical attackers, which lets it potentially punch a hole in the opposing team, but it does leave Bewear revenge killed more easily by Fire-types such as Salazzle and Houndoom.

Usage Tips

Choice Band Bewear is capable of dealing great immediate damage without requiring a turn to set up, which can allow it to threaten Pokemon like Metagross and Machamp much more easily in order to get more chances to wallbreak. Bring Bewear into battle by switching into resisted hits such as Golisopod's First Impression, after a teammate has fainted, on a double switch, or with the help of a pivot. Avoiding certain attacks like Knock Off can allow Bewear to bluff a Swords Dance set more easily, often dissuading the use of Protect from Pokemon such as Registeel and Vaporeon, which can otherwise safely scout what move Bewear locks itself into. While Bewear's bulk alongside Fluffy can allow it to take a hit from Pokemon like Metagross and Machamp, it may need to stay healthy in order to switch into other threats such as Golisopod and Tyrantrum.

Team Options

Entry hazard support from setters such as Necrozma, Roserade, and Forretress helps Bewear achieve various KOs. Necrozma and Roserade can also pressure certain physical walls such as opposing Forretress and Tangela, while Volt Switch from a partnering Forretress can get Bewear in safely. While Bewear can nail Psychic-types on the switch with Double-Edge, Pokemon capable of checking them like Golisopod and Houndoom are still appreciated, as Psychic-types can still pivot into Superpower and threaten Bewear if brought in safely. Pokemon such as Noivern and Dragalge can help check various threats to Bewear like Roserade and Salazzle while also drawing in Snorlax and Registeel, which creates an opening for Bewear to wallbreak. Dragalge is also able to absorb Toxic Spikes, which otherwise can wear Bewear down much more quickly. Cleaners such as Barbaracle and Shaymin appreciate Bewear's wallbreaking prowess and ability to pressure threats like Golisopod and Registeel, with Shaymin being capable of supporting Bewear with Healing Wish as well. Ghost-types are an issue even with proper coverage, as they are immune to both STAB moves, and locking Bewear into Shadow Claw can generate free turns for certain threats such as Barbaracle and Virizion, so having a Pursuit trapper such as Drapion, Houndoom, or Metagross could help ease Bewear's time wallbreaking.

Tsareena.overview: Tsareena is a viable spinner in the RU metagame, boasting a strong STAB move in Power Whip as well as Knock Off, which helps punish Ghost-types, which can attempt to block Rapid Spin, while High Jump Kick rounds up its coverage to hit Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Umbreon super effectively. In addition, Queenly Majesty makes Tsareena immune to priority moves, letting it serve as an offensive check to Mega Abomasnow and Honchkrow if it uses High Jump Kick. Tsareena's Speed puts it above base 70s such as Honchkrow and Metagross, but it's still slower than Mega Blastoise, Necrozma, and Nidoqueen, all of which can severely hurt Tsareena or KO it. Lastly, it competes with Virizion, Roserade, and Shaymin as an offensive Grass-type wallbreaker but has the niche of being a Rapid Spin user.
Tsareena.comments:
Other Options
